false-positive rate (e.g., 95%, meaning that only one-of-twenty human
inspections will yield an exploitable vulnerability).

AI.tldr: The paper discusses techniques for automatically detecting high-value vulnerabilities in smart contracts, having achieved over $3 million in bug bounties.
AI.motivation: To challenge the belief that automated techniques are only suitable for detecting minor vulnerabilities in blockchain systems and demonstrate their effectiveness in identifying high-value vulnerabilities.
AI.method: Combines high-completeness static analysis with domain knowledge, the latter being inferred either manually by experts or automatically using statistical analysis on a large corpus of deployed contracts.
AI.result: The techniques have successfully identified high-value vulnerabilities, leading to 10 disclosed bugs worth over $3M and hundreds of other bugs in under-audit or pre-deployment code.
AI.conclusion: High-value vulnerabilities can be detected automatically by prioritizing strategies with low false-negative rates, even at the cost of high false-positive rates, as long as the flagged cases deliver meaningful insights.

title: Signed Higher-Order Interactions for Brain Disorder Diagnosis via Multi-Channel Transformers
summary:
Accurately characterizing higher-order interactions of brain regions and
extracting interpretable organizational patterns from Functional Magnetic
Resonance Imaging data is crucial for brain disease diagnosis. Current
graph-based deep learning models primarily focus on pairwise or triadic
patterns while neglecting signed higher-order interactions, limiting
comprehensive understanding of brain-wide communication. We propose HOI-Brain,
a novel computational framework leveraging signed higher-order interactions and
organizational patterns in fMRI data for brain disease diagnosis. First, we
introduce a co-fluctuation measure based on Multiplication of Temporal
Derivatives to detect higher-order interactions with temporal resolution. We
then distinguish positive and negative synergistic interactions, encoding them
in signed weighted simplicial complexes to reveal brain communication insights.
Using Persistent Homology theory, we apply two filtration processes to these
complexes to extract signed higher-dimensional neural organizations
spatiotemporally. Finally, we propose a multi-channel brain Transformer to
integrate heterogeneous topological features. Experiments on Alzheimer' s
disease, Parkinson' s syndrome, and autism spectrum disorder datasets
demonstrate our framework' s superiority, effectiveness, and interpretability.
The identified key brain regions and higher-order patterns align with
neuroscience literature, providing meaningful biological insights.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a framework, HOI-Brain, that utilizes signed higher-order interactions and topological features in fMRI data to improve brain disease diagnosis.
AI.motivation: To overcome the limitations of current graph-based deep learning models, which largely ignore signed higher-order interactions and hinder a full understanding of complex brain communication.
AI.method: The authors developed a three-part computational pipeline: co-fluctuation assessment using Multiplication of Temporal Derivatives; encoding interactions in signed weighted simplicial complexes; and employing Persistent Homology theory with a multi-channel brain Transformer for feature integration.
AI.result: The proposed framework successfully diagnosed Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s syndrome, and autism spectrum disorder, aligning with established neuroscience literature.
AI.conclusion: HOI-Brain is a robust and interpretable framework for diagnosing brain diseases, offering biologically meaningful insights into brain communication pathways.

title: Refactoring $\neq$ Bug-Inducing: Improving Defect Prediction with Code Change Tactics Analysis
summary:
Just-in-time defect prediction (JIT-DP) aims to predict the likelihood of
code changes resulting in software defects at an early stage. Although code
change metrics and semantic features have enhanced prediction accuracy, prior
research has largely ignored code refactoring during both the evaluation and
methodology phases, despite its prevalence. Refactoring and its propagation
often tangle with bug-fixing and bug-inducing changes within the same commit
and statement. Neglecting refactoring can introduce bias into the learning and
evaluation of JIT-DP models. To address this gap, we investigate the impact of
refactoring and its propagation on six state-of-the-art JIT-DP approaches. We
propose Code chAnge Tactics (CAT) analysis to categorize code refactoring and
its propagation, which improves labeling accuracy in the JIT-Defects4J dataset
by 13.7%. Our experiments reveal that failing to consider refactoring
information in the dataset can diminish the performance of models, particularly
semantic-based models, by 18.6% and 37.3% in F1-score. Additionally, we propose
integrating refactoring information to enhance six baseline approaches,
resulting in overall improvements in recall and F1-score, with increases of up
to 43.2% and 32.5%, respectively. Our research underscores the importance of
incorporating refactoring information in the methodology and evaluation of
JIT-DP. Furthermore, our CAT has broad applicability in analyzing refactoring
and its propagation for software maintenance.

AI.tldr: This paper addresses the overlooked effect of code refactoring on just-in-time defect prediction (JIT-DP) and proposes improvements using the Code chAnge Tactics (CAT) analysis, which enhances model performance significantly.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to investigate the largely ignored role of code refactoring in the evaluation and methodology of JIT-DP models, given its potential to introduce biases and hinder prediction accuracy.
AI.method: The authors developed a Code chAnge Tactics (CAT) analysis approach to identify and categorize the effects of refactoring and its propagation, improving the labeling accuracy of the JIT-Defects4J dataset.
AI.result: Using CAT analysis, labeling accuracy increased by 13.7%, while integrating refactoring information significantly improved baseline model performance, achieving up to 43.2% improvement in recall and 32.5% in F1-score.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating code refactoring information in JIT-DP enhances prediction accuracy and mitigates biases, and the proposed CAT method provides a general tool for analyzing refactoring in software maintenance.

title: Bag of Coins: A Statistical Probe into Neural Confidence Structures
summary:
Modern neural networks, despite their high accuracy, often produce poorly
calibrated confidence scores, limiting their reliability in high-stakes
applications. Existing calibration methods typically post-process model outputs
without interrogating the internal consistency of the predictions themselves.
In this work, we introduce a novel, non-parametric statistical probe, the
Bag-of-Coins (BoC) test, that examines the internal consistency of a
classifier's logits. The BoC test reframes confidence estimation as a
frequentist hypothesis test: does the model's top-ranked class win 1-v-1
contests against random competitors at a rate consistent with its own stated
softmax probability? When applied to modern deep learning architectures, this
simple probe reveals a fundamental dichotomy. On Vision Transformers (ViTs),
the BoC output serves as a state-of-the-art confidence score, achieving
near-perfect calibration with an ECE of 0.0212, an 88% improvement over a
temperature-scaled baseline. Conversely, on Convolutional Neural Networks
(CNNs) like ResNet, the probe reveals a deep inconsistency between the model's
predictions and its internal logit structure, a property missed by traditional
metrics. We posit that BoC is not merely a calibration method, but a new
diagnostic tool for understanding and exposing the differing ways that popular
architectures represent uncertainty.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces the Bag-of-Coins (BoC) test, a novel method for assessing the internal consistency of neural network confidence scores, and demonstrates its efficacy on Vision Transformers (ViTs) while identifying discrepancies in Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs).
AI.motivation: Modern neural networks often provide poorly calibrated confidence scores, which hinder their reliability in critical applications. Existing calibration methods fail to explore internal consistency, highlighting the need for a new approach.
AI.method: The Bag-of-Coins (BoC) test is implemented as a non-parametric statistical probe that reframes confidence estimation as a frequentist hypothesis test, examining whether a model's top-ranked class outperforms random competitors at a rate consistent with its softmax probability.
AI.result: On Vision Transformers, BoC achieves near-perfect calibration with an Expected Calibration Error (ECE) of 0.0212, significantly outperforming temperature-scaled baselines. On CNNs like ResNet, BoC reveals inconsistencies between predictions and internal logit structures.
AI.conclusion: BoC serves as both a state-of-the-art calibration method for certain architectures and a diagnostic tool for exposing how different neural network types represent uncertainty, advancing the understanding of model confidence in modern deep learning.

title: GABRIL: Gaze-Based Regularization for Mitigating Causal Confusion in Imitation Learning
comment: IROS 2025 camera-ready version. First two authors contributed equally
summary:
Imitation Learning (IL) is a widely adopted approach which enables agents to
learn from human expert demonstrations by framing the task as a supervised
learning problem. However, IL often suffers from causal confusion, where agents
misinterpret spurious correlations as causal relationships, leading to poor
performance in testing environments with distribution shift. To address this
issue, we introduce GAze-Based Regularization in Imitation Learning (GABRIL), a
novel method that leverages the human gaze data gathered during the data
collection phase to guide the representation learning in IL. GABRIL utilizes a
regularization loss which encourages the model to focus on causally relevant
features identified through expert gaze and consequently mitigates the effects
of confounding variables. We validate our approach in Atari environments and
the Bench2Drive benchmark in CARLA by collecting human gaze datasets and
applying our method in both domains. Experimental results show that the
improvement of GABRIL over behavior cloning is around 179% more than the same
number for other baselines in the Atari and 76% in the CARLA setup. Finally, we
show that our method provides extra explainability when compared to regular IL
agents.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces GABRIL, a method incorporating human gaze data into imitation learning to mitigate causal confusion, and demonstrates improved performance and explainability in Atari and CARLA benchmarks.
AI.motivation: To address causal confusion in imitation learning, where models misinterpret spurious correlations as causal relationships, often leading to poor generalization in new environments.
AI.method: The authors propose GABRIL, which uses human gaze data collected during expert demonstrations as a regularization loss to guide representation learning and focus on causally relevant features.
AI.result: GABRIL significantly improves performance over behavior cloning with a 179% performance boost in Atari environments and 76% in CARLA benchmarks, compared to other baselines.
AI.conclusion: Integrating human gaze data into imitation learning helps mitigate causal confusion, improves agent performance, and provides enhanced explainability.

title: Mind the Language Gap in Digital Humanities: LLM-Aided Translation of SKOS Thesauri
summary:
We introduce WOKIE, an open-source, modular, and ready-to-use pipeline for
the automated translation of SKOS thesauri. This work addresses a critical need
in the Digital Humanities (DH), where language diversity can limit access,
reuse, and semantic interoperability of knowledge resources. WOKIE combines
external translation services with targeted refinement using Large Language
Models (LLMs), balancing translation quality, scalability, and cost. Designed
to run on everyday hardware and be easily extended, the application requires no
prior expertise in machine translation or LLMs. We evaluate WOKIE across
several DH thesauri in 15 languages with different parameters, translation
services and LLMs, systematically analysing translation quality, performance,
and ontology matching improvements. Our results show that WOKIE is suitable to
enhance the accessibility, reuse, and cross-lingual interoperability of
thesauri by hurdle-free automated translation and improved ontology matching
performance, supporting more inclusive and multilingual research
infrastructures.

AI.tldr: WOKIE is an open-source pipeline that facilitates automated, high-quality, and cost-effective translation of SKOS thesauri, leveraging external services and Large Language Models.
AI.motivation: Address the issue of language diversity restricting access, reuse, and interoperability of knowledge resources in Digital Humanities.
AI.method: Utilizes modular architecture combining external translation services and refinement by Large Language Models, with systematic evaluation against DH thesauri in 15 languages.
AI.result: Demonstrates improved translation quality, scalability, accessibility and enhanced ontology matching performance in multilingual context.
AI.conclusion: WOKIE aids the development of inclusive and multilingual research infrastructures by overcoming translation barriers and fostering semantic interoperability in DH.

title: Wavelet Logic Machines: Learning and Reasoning in the Spectral Domain Without Neural Networks
summary:
We introduce a fully spectral learning framework that eliminates traditional
neural layers by operating entirely in the wavelet domain. The model applies
learnable nonlinear transformations, including soft-thresholding and gain-phase
modulation, directly to wavelet coefficients. It also includes a differentiable
wavelet basis selection mechanism, enabling adaptive processing using families
such as Haar, Daubechies, and Biorthogonal wavelets.
  Implemented in PyTorch with full 3D support, the model maintains a spectral
pipeline without spatial convolutions or attention. On synthetic 3D denoising
and natural language tasks from the GLUE benchmark, including SST-2 sentiment
classification, the model achieves 89.3 percent accuracy, close to a 4-layer
Transformer baseline (90.1 percent), while using 72 percent fewer parameters
and 58 percent less peak memory. Faster early convergence is observed due to
spectral sparsity priors.
  In contrast to the quadratic complexity of self-attention and large matrix
multiplications in Transformers, our approach uses linear-time wavelet
transforms and pointwise nonlinearities, significantly reducing inference cost.
This yields a compact, interpretable, and efficient alternative to neural
models. Our results support the viability of principled spectral learning in
both vision and language tasks, offering new directions for model design
without overparameterized architectures.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a model operating entirely in the wavelet domain, avoiding traditional neural layers while achieving efficiency and competitive performance.
AI.motivation: To create an efficient and interpretable learning model by leveraging wavelet domain processing instead of overparameterized architectures like Transformers.
AI.method: The model applies learnable nonlinear transformations directly to wavelet coefficients, utilizing differentiable wavelet basis selection for adaptive processing.
AI.result: Achieved 89.3% accuracy on SST-2 sentiment classification with 72% fewer parameters and 58% less peak memory compared to a 4-layer Transformer.
AI.conclusion: The approach demonstrates the potential of spectral learning to provide compact and efficient alternatives to traditional neural architectures in vision and language tasks.

title: T-MPEDNet: Unveiling the Synergy of Transformer-aware Multiscale Progressive Encoder-Decoder Network with Feature Recalibration for Tumor and Liver Segmentation
summary:
Precise and automated segmentation of the liver and its tumor within CT scans
plays a pivotal role in swift diagnosis and the development of optimal
treatment plans for individuals with liver diseases and malignancies. However,
automated liver and tumor segmentation faces significant hurdles arising from
the inherent heterogeneity of tumors and the diverse visual characteristics of
livers across a broad spectrum of patients. Aiming to address these challenges,
we present a novel Transformer-aware Multiscale Progressive Encoder-Decoder
Network (T-MPEDNet) for automated segmentation of tumor and liver. T-MPEDNet
leverages a deep adaptive features backbone through a progressive
encoder-decoder structure, enhanced by skip connections for recalibrating
channel-wise features while preserving spatial integrity. A
Transformer-inspired dynamic attention mechanism captures long-range contextual
relationships within the spatial domain, further enhanced by multi-scale
feature utilization for refined local details, leading to accurate prediction.
Morphological boundary refinement is then employed to address indistinct
boundaries with neighboring organs, capturing finer details and yielding
precise boundary labels. The efficacy of T-MPEDNet is comprehensively assessed
on two widely utilized public benchmark datasets, LiTS and 3DIRCADb. Extensive
quantitative and qualitative analyses demonstrate the superiority of T-MPEDNet
compared to twelve state-of-the-art methods. On LiTS, T-MPEDNet achieves
outstanding Dice Similarity Coefficients (DSC) of 97.6% and 89.1% for liver and
tumor segmentation, respectively. Similar performance is observed on 3DIRCADb,
with DSCs of 98.3% and 83.3% for liver and tumor segmentation, respectively.
Our findings prove that T-MPEDNet is an efficacious and reliable framework for
automated segmentation of the liver and its tumor in CT scans.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces T-MPEDNet, a Transformer-based deep learning model, to enhance automated liver and tumor segmentation in CT scans, achieving superior performance over state-of-the-art methods.
AI.motivation: Automated liver and tumor segmentation in CT scans is challenging due to tumor heterogeneity and diverse liver characteristics across patients, requiring advanced solutions for precise diagnosis and treatment planning.
AI.method: The study develops T-MPEDNet, a Transformer-based multiscale encoder-decoder network with dynamic attention, progressive feature learning, and boundary refinement techniques to improve segmentation accuracy.
AI.result: On benchmark datasets LiTS and 3DIRCADb, T-MPEDNet achieves highly accurate Dice Similarity Coefficients, surpassing twelve state-of-the-art methods.
AI.conclusion: T-MPEDNet is a robust and effective framework for automated liver and tumor segmentation, offering a promising tool for clinical applications.

title: RoCE BALBOA: Service-enhanced Data Center RDMA for SmartNICs
summary:
Data-intensive applications in data centers, especially machine learning
(ML), have made the network a bottleneck, which in turn has motivated the
development of more efficient network protocols and infrastructure. For
instance, remote direct memory access (RDMA) has become the standard protocol
for data transport in the cloud as it minimizes data copies and reduces
CPU-utilization via host-bypassing. Similarly, an increasing amount of network
functions and infrastructure have moved to accelerators, SmartNICs, and
in-network computing to bypass the CPU. In this paper we explore the
implementation and deployment of RoCE BALBOA, an open-source, RoCE
v2-compatible, scalable up to hundreds of queue-pairs, and 100G-capable
RDMA-stack that can be used as the basis for building accelerators and
smartNICs. RoCE BALBOA is customizable, opening up a design space and offering
a degree of adaptability not available in commercial products. We have deployed
BALBOA in a cluster using FPGAs and show that it has latency and performance
characteristics comparable to commercial NICs. We demonstrate its potential by
exploring two classes of use cases. One involves enhancements to the protocol
for infrastructure purposes (encryption, deep packet inspection using ML). The
other showcases the ability to perform line-rate compute offloads with deep
pipelines by implementing commercial data preprocessing pipelines for
recommender systems that process the data as it arrives from the network before
transferring it directly to the GPU. These examples demonstrate how BALBOA
enables the exploration and development of SmartNICs and accelerators operating
on network data streams.

AI.tldr: The paper presents RoCE BALBOA, an open-source and customizable RDMA-stack designed for machine learning and data-intensive applications in data centers, showing performance comparable to commercial NICs while enabling new use cases in SmartNICs and accelerators.
AI.motivation: Modern data centers face a network bottleneck due to increasingly data-intensive applications like machine learning, necessitating advancements in network protocols and infrastructure such as RDMA and SmartNICs for performance optimization.
AI.method: The authors design and implement RoCE BALBOA, an open-source, RoCE v2-compatible RDMA-stack deployed on FPGAs, which is capable of supporting hundreds of queue pairs and 100G throughput. They demonstrate its customizability and use cases by exploring protocol enhancements and deep packet inspection.
AI.result: RoCE BALBOA was deployed on an FPGA-based cluster and showed latency and performance comparable to commercial NICs. It enabled the development of advanced use cases like in-network encryption, machine learning-based packet inspection, and commercial data preprocessing for recommender systems.
AI.conclusion: RoCE BALBOA provides a flexible, high-performance platform for deploying and experimenting with SmartNICs and accelerators, offering adaptability that is not available in commercial solutions and fostering innovation in in-network computing.

title: MegatronApp: Efficient and Comprehensive Management on Distributed LLM Training
summary:
The rapid escalation in the parameter count of large language models (LLMs)
has transformed model training from a single-node endeavor into a highly
intricate, cross-node activity. While frameworks such as Megatron-LM
successfully integrate tensor (TP), pipeline (PP), and data (DP) parallelism to
enable trillion-parameter training, they simultaneously expose practitioners to
unprecedented systems-level challenges in performance optimization, diagnosis,
and interpretability. MegatronApp is an open-source toolchain expressly
designed to meet these challenges. It introduces four orthogonal, yet
seamlessly composable modules--MegaScan, MegaFBD, MegaDPP, and MegaScope--that
collectively elevate the reliability, efficiency, and transparency of
production-scale training. This paper presents the motivation, architecture,
and distinctive contributions of each module, and elucidates how their
synergistic integration augments the Megatron-LM ecosystem.

AI.tldr: MegatronApp is an open-source toolchain aimed at addressing system-level challenges in training large language models (LLMs), enhancing reliability, efficiency, and transparency.
AI.motivation: To tackle system-level challenges like optimization, diagnosis, and interpretability in training trillion-parameter large language models.
AI.method: Introduced an open-source toolchain with four composable modules (MegaScan, MegaFBD, MegaDPP, MegaScope) to elevate training capabilities and integrate synergistically with Megatron-LM.
AI.result: The four modules collectively improve the performance, diagnostic capabilities, and interpretability of production-scale training.
AI.conclusion: MegatronApp provides a systematic solution for enhancing the Megatron-LM ecosystem, addressing scalability and reliability in LLM training workflows.

title: NACHOS: Neural Architecture Search for Hardware Constrained Early Exit Neural Networks
summary:
Early Exit Neural Networks (EENNs) endow astandard Deep Neural Network (DNN)
with Early Exit Classifiers (EECs), to provide predictions at intermediate
points of the processing when enough confidence in classification is achieved.
This leads to many benefits in terms of effectiveness and efficiency.
Currently, the design of EENNs is carried out manually by experts, a complex
and time-consuming task that requires accounting for many aspects, including
the correct placement, the thresholding, and the computational overhead of the
EECs. For this reason, the research is exploring the use of Neural Architecture
Search (NAS) to automatize the design of EENNs. Currently, few comprehensive
NAS solutions for EENNs have been proposed in the literature, and a fully
automated, joint design strategy taking into consideration both the backbone
and the EECs remains an open problem. To this end, this work presents Neural
Architecture Search for Hardware Constrained Early Exit Neural Networks
(NACHOS), the first NAS framework for the design of optimal EENNs satisfying
constraints on the accuracy and the number of Multiply and Accumulate (MAC)
operations performed by the EENNs at inference time. In particular, this
provides the joint design of backbone and EECs to select a set of admissible
(i.e., respecting the constraints) Pareto Optimal Solutions in terms of best
tradeoff between the accuracy and number of MACs. The results show that the
models designed by NACHOS are competitive with the state-of-the-art EENNs.
Additionally, this work investigates the effectiveness of two novel
regularization terms designed for the optimization of the auxiliary classifiers
of the EENN

AI.tldr: Neural Architecture Search for Hardware Constrained Early Exit Neural Networks (NACHOS) automatically designs Early Exit Neural Networks (EENNs), optimizing their performance under computational constraints.
AI.motivation: The manual design of Early Exit Neural Networks (EENNs) is complex and challenging, requiring expertise to address various aspects like classifier placement, confidence thresholds, and efficiency. Automating this process can reduce complexity and improve results.
AI.method: NACHOS employs Neural Architecture Search (NAS) to automate the design of EENNs, enabling joint optimization of the backbone network and early exit classifiers under constraints related to accuracy and computational costs.
AI.result: The models generated by NACHOS provide a set of Pareto Optimal solutions balancing accuracy and computational efficiency, and these models are comparable to the state-of-the-art EENNs.
AI.conclusion: NACHOS demonstrates that automated NAS processes can effectively design hardware-constrained EENNs, offering high-quality solutions while addressing constraints. Additional regularization terms further enhance auxiliary classifier optimization.

title: DeltaLLM: A Training-Free Framework Exploiting Temporal Sparsity for Efficient Edge LLM Inference
summary:
Deploying Large Language Models (LLMs) on edge devices remains challenging
due to their quadratically increasing computations with the sequence length.
Existing studies for dynamic attention pruning are designed for hardware with
massively parallel computation capabilities, such as GPUs or TPUs, and aim at
long context lengths (e.g., 64K), making them unsuitable for edge scenarios. We
present DeltaLLM, a training-free framework that exploits temporal sparsity in
attention patterns to enable efficient LLM inference across both the prefilling
and decoding stages, on resource-constrained edge devices. DeltaLLM introduces
an accuracy- and memory-aware delta matrix construction strategy that
introduces temporal sparsity, and a context-aware hybrid attention mechanism
that combines full attention in a local context window with delta approximation
outside it to increase accuracy. We evaluate our framework on the
edge-device-friendly BitNet-b1.58-2B-4T model and Llama3.2-1B-Instruct model
across diverse language tasks. The results show that on BitNet, our framework
increases the attention sparsity from 0% to 60% during the prefilling stage
with slight accuracy improvement on the WG task, and 0% to 57% across both the
prefilling and decoding stages, with even higher F1 score from 29.63 to 30.97
on SQuAD-v2 task. On the Llama model, it can also achieve up to 60% sparsity
during the prefilling stage and around 57% across both stages with negligible
accuracy drop. These results demonstrate that DeltaLLM offers a promising
solution for efficient edge deployment, requiring no fine-tuning and seamlessly
integrating with existing inference pipelines.

AI.tldr: DeltaLLM introduces a training-free method leveraging temporal sparsity for efficient inference of large language models (LLMs) on edge devices, improving computational efficiency without sacrificing accuracy.
AI.motivation: Current methods for deploying LLMs are incompatible with edge devices due to high computational requirements and their focus on long context lengths optimized for GPUs or TPUs.
AI.method: DeltaLLM introduces a temporal sparsity-aware delta matrix construction strategy and a hybrid attention mechanism combining full attention in local contexts with delta approximation for reduced computation and increased accuracy.
AI.result: DeltaLLM achieves up to 60% attention sparsity in the prefilling stage and 57% in both prefilling and decoding, with marginal or slight accuracy improvements using BitNet and Llama models across tasks such as WG and SQuAD-v2.
AI.conclusion: DeltaLLM delivers an efficient solution for LLM inference on edge devices without requiring fine-tuning, showing potential for scalability and integration in resource-constrained scenarios.

title: LLM-Based Repair of Static Nullability Errors
summary:
Modern Java projects increasingly adopt static analysis tools that prevent
null-pointer exceptions by treating nullness as a type property. However,
integrating such tools into large, existing codebases remains a significant
challenge. While annotation inference can eliminate many errors automatically,
a subset of residual errors -- typically a mix of real bugs and false positives
-- often persist and can only be resolved via code changes. Manually addressing
these errors is tedious and error-prone. Large language models (LLMs) offer a
promising path toward automating these repairs, but naively-prompted LLMs often
generate incorrect, contextually-inappropriate edits. Resolving a nullability
error demands a deep understanding of how a symbol is used across the codebase,
often spanning methods, classes, and packages. We present NullRepair, a system
that integrates LLMs into a structured workflow for resolving the errors from a
nullability checker. NullRepair's decision process follows a flowchart derived
from manual analysis of 200 real-world errors. It leverages static analysis to
identify safe and unsafe usage regions of symbols, using error-free usage
examples to contextualize model prompts. Patches are generated through an
iterative interaction with the LLM that incorporates project-wide context and
decision logic. Our evaluation on 12 real-world Java projects shows that
NullRepair resolves an average of 72% of the errors that remain after applying
a state-of-the-art annotation inference technique. Unlike a naively-prompted
LLM, NullRepair also largely preserves program semantics, with all unit tests
passing in 10/12 projects after applying every edit proposed by NullRepair, and
98% or more tests passing in the remaining two projects.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces NullRepair, a tool that utilizes large language models (LLMs) in a structured workflow to address nullability errors in Java projects. It resolves errors effectively while maintaining program correctness.
AI.motivation: Manually resolving nullability errors remaining after static analysis is tedious and error-prone. This motivates the need for an automated and reliable solution that integrates deep understanding of codebase context.
AI.method: NullRepair integrates LLMs into a structured approach based on a flowchart derived from real-world error analysis. It uses static analysis to define safe/unsafe regions and contextualizes prompts with error-free examples. Edits are iteratively generated, incorporating project-wide context.
AI.result: NullRepair was evaluated on 12 Java projects and resolved 72% of nullability errors left after applying a state-of-the-art annotation inference. It largely preserved program semantics, with all or nearly all unit tests passing in evaluated projects.
AI.conclusion: NullRepair provides a robust, automated solution that effectively and safely resolves nullability errors, demonstrating its potential for practical deployment in large Java projects.

title: Comparing and Scaling fMRI Features for Brain-Behavior Prediction
summary:
Predicting behavioral variables from neuroimaging modalities such as magnetic
resonance imaging (MRI) has the potential to allow the development of
neuroimaging biomarkers of mental and neurological disorders. A crucial
processing step to this aim is the extraction of suitable features. These can
differ in how well they predict the target of interest, and how this prediction
scales with sample size and scan time. Here, we compare nine feature subtypes
extracted from resting-state functional MRI recordings for behavior prediction,
ranging from regional measures of functional activity to functional
connectivity (FC) and metrics derived with graph signal processing (GSP), a
principled approach for the extraction of structure-informed functional
features. We study 979 subjects from the Human Connectome Project Young Adult
dataset, predicting summary scores for mental health, cognition, processing
speed, and substance use, as well as age and sex. The scaling properties of the
features are investigated for different combinations of sample size and scan
time. FC comes out as the best feature for predicting cognition, age, and sex.
Graph power spectral density is the second best for predicting cognition and
age, while for sex, variability-based features show potential as well. When
predicting sex, the low-pass graph filtered coupled FC slightly outperforms the
simple FC variant. None of the other targets were predicted significantly. The
scaling results point to higher performance reserves for the better-performing
features. They also indicate that it is important to balance sample size and
scan time when acquiring data for prediction studies. The results confirm FC as
a robust feature for behavior prediction, but also show the potential of GSP
and variability-based measures. We discuss the implications for future
prediction studies in terms of strategies for acquisition and sample
composition.

AI.tldr: This study compares nine feature subtypes derived from resting-state fMRI recordings for predicting behavioral variables, identifying functional connectivity (FC) as the best predictor for cognition, age, and sex.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to improve predictions of behavioral and demographic variables using neuroimaging, which could lead to biomarkers for mental and neurological disorders.
AI.method: The study analyzes data from 979 subjects using features extracted from resting-state fMRI, including functional connectivity (FC) and graph-based signal processing (GSP), and tests predictions against various behavioral and demographic targets.
AI.result: Functional connectivity (FC) outperformed other features in predicting cognition, age, and sex. Variability-based and graph signal processing features also showed promise.
AI.conclusion: FC is validated as a robust predictor for behavioral features, yet other feature types like GSP and variability-based measures show potential, especially for sex prediction. The trade-off between sample size and scan time is critical.

title: Clean Code In Practice: Challenges and Opportunities
summary:
Reliability prediction is crucial for ensuring the safety and security of
software systems, especially in the context of industry practices. While
various metrics and measurements are employed to assess software reliability,
the complexity of modern systems necessitates a deeper understanding of how
these metrics interact with security and safety concerns. This paper explores
the interplay between software reliability, safety, and security, offering a
comprehensive analysis of key metrics and measurement techniques used in the
industry for reliability prediction. We identify critical threats to software
reliability and provide a threat estimation framework that incorporates both
safety and security aspects. Our findings suggest that integrating reliability
metrics with safety and security considerations can enhance the robustness of
software systems. Furthermore, we propose a set of actionable guidelines for
practitioners to improve their reliability prediction models while
simultaneously addressing the security and safety challenges of contemporary
software applications.

AI.tldr: The paper examines how software reliability metrics interact with safety and security considerations, proposing a framework to improve reliability prediction and actionable guidelines for industry practitioners.
AI.motivation: The increasing complexity of modern software systems requires an integrated approach to address reliability alongside safety and security concerns.
AI.method: The authors analyze industry metrics for reliability prediction, identify threats to software reliability, and develop a threat estimation framework combining safety and security dimensions.
AI.result: The integration of reliability metrics with safety and security considerations is shown to enhance system robustness.
AI.conclusion: The study offers actionable guidelines to refine reliability prediction models and address multifaceted challenges within software safety and security contexts.

title: Sparse-mode Dynamic Mode Decomposition for Disambiguating Local and Global Structures
summary:
The dynamic mode decomposition (DMD) is a data-driven approach that extracts
the dominant features from spatiotemporal data. In this work, we introduce
sparse-mode DMD, a new variant of the optimized DMD framework that specifically
leverages sparsity-promoting regularization in order to approximate DMD modes
which have localized spatial structure. The algorithm maintains the
noise-robust properties of optimized DMD while disambiguating between modes
which are spatially local versus global in nature. In many applications, such
modes are associated with discrete and continuous spectra respectively, thus
allowing the algorithm to explicitly construct, in an unsupervised manner, the
distinct portions of the spectrum. We demonstrate this by analyzing synthetic
and real-world systems, including examples from optical waveguides, quantum
mechanics, and sea surface temperature data.

AI.tldr: Sparse-mode DMD is a novel extension of optimized DMD that uses sparsity-promoting regularization to approximate spatially localized modes from spatiotemporal data.
AI.motivation: Current optimized DMD methods sometimes fail to distinguish between spatially localized and global modes, which limits effectiveness in applications requiring differentiation of discrete and continuous spectra.
AI.method: The paper introduces a sparsity-promoting regularization technique within the optimized DMD framework to isolate spatially localized modes. Synthetic and real-world systems are analyzed as test cases.
AI.result: Sparse-mode DMD successfully identifies spatially localized modes while maintaining noise robustness, allowing for the differentiation of discrete and continuous spectra in various settings.
AI.conclusion: The sparse-mode DMD enhances DMD's capability to extract localized structures, offering a robust and effective tool for analyzing diverse datasets and spectrums in an unsupervised and automated manner.

title: RAKOMO: Reachability-Aware K-Order Markov Path Optimization for Quadrupedal Loco-Manipulation
summary:
Legged manipulators, such as quadrupeds equipped with robotic arms, require
motion planning techniques that account for their complex kinematic constraints
in order to perform manipulation tasks both safely and effectively. However,
trajectory optimization methods often face challenges due to the hybrid
dynamics introduced by contact discontinuities, and tend to neglect leg
limitations during planning for computational reasons. In this work, we propose
RAKOMO, a path optimization technique that integrates the strengths of K-Order
Markov Optimization (KOMO) with a kinematically-aware criterion based on the
reachable region defined as reachability margin. We leverage a neural-network
to predict the margin and optimize it by incorporating it in the standard KOMO
formulation. This approach enables rapid convergence of gradient-based motion
planning -- commonly tailored for continuous systems -- while adapting it
effectively to legged manipulators, successfully executing loco-manipulation
tasks. We benchmark RAKOMO against a baseline KOMO approach through a set of
simulations for pick-and-place tasks with the HyQReal quadruped robot equipped
with a Kinova Gen3 robotic arm.

AI.tldr: RAKOMO is a novel trajectory optimization method for legged manipulators combining K-Order Markov Optimization with a neural-network-based reachability margin for improved loco-manipulation.
AI.motivation: Legged robots require precise motion planning to perform manipulation tasks safely, but existing methods struggle with hybrid dynamics and leg constraints.
AI.method: RAKOMO integrates KOMO optimization with a neural network-based kinematically-aware criterion called reachability margin.
AI.result: RAKOMO showed faster convergence and better adaptability compared to baseline methods in simulation tests with a quadruped robot performing pick-and-place tasks.
AI.conclusion: RAKOMO enhances trajectory optimization for legged locomotion and manipulation tasks, combining neural network predictions with standard optimization techniques.

title: Mitigating Geospatial Knowledge Hallucination in Large Language Models: Benchmarking and Dynamic Factuality Aligning
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) possess extensive world knowledge, including
geospatial knowledge, which has been successfully applied to various geospatial
tasks such as mobility prediction and social indicator prediction. However,
LLMs often generate inaccurate geospatial knowledge, leading to geospatial
hallucinations (incorrect or inconsistent representations of geospatial
information) that compromise their reliability. While the phenomenon of general
knowledge hallucination in LLMs has been widely studied, the systematic
evaluation and mitigation of geospatial hallucinations remain largely
unexplored. To address this gap, we propose a comprehensive evaluation
framework for geospatial hallucinations, leveraging structured geospatial
knowledge graphs for controlled assessment. Through extensive evaluation across
20 advanced LLMs, we uncover the hallucinations in their geospatial knowledge.
Building on these insights, we introduce a dynamic factuality aligning method
based on Kahneman-Tversky Optimization (KTO) to mitigate geospatial
hallucinations in LLMs, leading to a performance improvement of over 29.6% on
the proposed benchmark. Extensive experimental results demonstrate the
effectiveness of our benchmark and learning algorithm in enhancing the
trustworthiness of LLMs in geospatial knowledge and reasoning tasks.

AI.tldr: This paper addresses the issue of geospatial hallucinations (factually incorrect geospatial information) in large language models (LLMs), introduces a benchmark to evaluate these hallucinations, and proposes a mitigation method based on Kahneman-Tversky Optimization.
AI.motivation: Geospatial hallucinations in LLMs undermine their reliability in tasks requiring accurate geospatial reasoning and knowledge. Existing studies on general hallucinations don't adequately address this issue.
AI.method: The paper proposes a benchmark leveraging structured geospatial knowledge graphs to systematically evaluate geospatial hallucinations. It also introduces a dynamic factuality alignment method using Kahneman-Tversky Optimization (KTO) to reduce such hallucinations.
AI.result: Extensive evaluations of 20 advanced LLMs reveal prevalent geospatial hallucinations in their knowledge. The proposed KTO method reduces these hallucinations, improving performance by over 29.6% on the benchmark.
AI.conclusion: The paper enhances the trustworthiness of LLMs in geospatial tasks by providing an effective evaluation framework and mitigation strategy. This approach shows significant potential for improving the factual accuracy of LLMs regarding geospatial information.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Traditional and Deep Learning Time Series Architectures for Influenza A Infectious Disease Forecasting
summary:
Influenza A is responsible for 290,000 to 650,000 respiratory deaths a year,
though this estimate is an improvement from years past due to improvements in
sanitation, healthcare practices, and vaccination programs. In this study, we
perform a comparative analysis of traditional and deep learning models to
predict Influenza A outbreaks. Using historical data from January 2009 to
December 2023, we compared the performance of traditional ARIMA and Exponential
Smoothing(ETS) models with six distinct deep learning architectures: Simple
RNN, LSTM, GRU, BiLSTM, BiGRU, and Transformer. The results reveal a clear
superiority of all the deep learning models, especially the state-of-the-art
Transformer with respective average testing MSE and MAE of 0.0433 \pm 0.0020
and 0.1126 \pm 0.0016 for capturing the temporal complexities associated with
Influenza A data, outperforming well known traditional baseline ARIMA and ETS
models. These findings of this study provide evidence that state-of-the-art
deep learning architectures can enhance predictive modeling for infectious
diseases and indicate a more general trend toward using deep learning methods
to enhance public health forecasting and intervention planning strategies.
Future work should focus on how these models can be incorporated into real-time
forecasting and preparedness systems at an epidemic level, and integrated into
existing surveillance systems.

AI.tldr: This paper evaluates deep learning models for predicting Influenza A outbreaks and finds that they outperform traditional models like ARIMA and ETS, with the Transformer showing the best results.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to improve predictive modeling for Influenza A outbreaks using advanced deep learning methods, given the public health significance of preventing respiratory deaths.
AI.method: The study uses historical data (2009-2023) to compare traditional models (ARIMA, ETS) against six deep learning architectures: Simple RNN, LSTM, GRU, BiLSTM, BiGRU, and Transformer. Performance is evaluated using metrics like MSE and MAE.
AI.result: Deep learning models significantly outperform traditional approaches, with the Transformer achieving the best predictive accuracy (MSE: 0.0433 ± 0.0020, MAE: 0.1126 ± 0.0016).
AI.conclusion: Deep learning, especially the Transformer architecture, offers a superior approach to forecasting Influenza A outbreaks. Its adoption could improve public health monitoring and intervention systems.

title: SurgPIS: Surgical-instrument-level Instances and Part-level Semantics for Weakly-supervised Part-aware Instance Segmentation
summary:
Consistent surgical instrument segmentation is critical for automation in
robot-assisted surgery. Yet, existing methods only treat instrument-level
instance segmentation (IIS) or part-level semantic segmentation (PSS)
separately, without interaction between these tasks. In this work, we formulate
a surgical tool segmentation as a unified part-aware instance segmentation
(PIS) problem and introduce SurgPIS, the first PIS model for surgical
instruments. Our method adopts a transformer-based mask classification approach
and introduces part-specific queries derived from instrument-level object
queries, explicitly linking parts to their parent instrument instances. In
order to address the lack of large-scale datasets with both instance- and
part-level labels, we propose a weakly-supervised learning strategy for SurgPIS
to learn from disjoint datasets labelled for either IIS or PSS purposes. During
training, we aggregate our PIS predictions into IIS or PSS masks, thereby
allowing us to compute a loss against partially labelled datasets. A
student-teacher approach is developed to maintain prediction consistency for
missing PIS information in the partially labelled data, e.g., parts of the IIS
labelled data. Extensive experiments across multiple datasets validate the
effectiveness of SurgPIS, achieving state-of-the-art performance in PIS as well
as IIS, PSS, and instrument-level semantic segmentation.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces SurgPIS, a novel part-aware instance segmentation (PIS) model for surgical instruments, which unifies both instance-level and part-level segmentation tasks with a transformer-based approach.
AI.motivation: The existing methods for segmenting surgical instruments separately address instance-level (IIS) or part-level (PSS) segmentation, lacking interaction between these tasks. A unified approach is necessary for consistent segmentation, which is crucial for robot-assisted surgery.
AI.method: The method involves a unified part-aware instance segmentation (PIS) with a transformer-based mask classification system. Part-specific queries link parts to parent instances. A weakly-supervised learning strategy allows training on datasets labeled either for IIS or PSS by aggregating PIS predictions and implementing a student-teacher approach for partial labeling.
AI.result: Extensive experiments demonstrate that SurgPIS achieves state-of-the-art performance in part-aware instance segmentation (PIS) and performs strongly in IIS, PSS, and instrument-level semantic segmentation across multiple datasets.
AI.conclusion: SurgPIS successfully addresses the lack of interaction between instance-level and part-level surgical instrument segmentation. The weakly-supervised learning and transformer-based design make it effective and versatile for surgical automation tasks.

title: Demystifying the 7-D Convolution Loop Nest for Data and Instruction Streaming in Reconfigurable AI Accelerators
summary:
Convolution remains the most compute-intensive operation in AI acceleration,
often constituting over 80-90% of the workload. Existing approaches in spatial
architectures such as coarse-grained reconfigurable arrays (CGRAs) and
field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs) frequently rely on loop unrolling or
GEMM-based matrix transformations, introducing significant overhead in both
data movement and instruction control. This paper presents a new framework
designed to systematically demystify the 7-dimensional convolution loop nest by
reinterpreting it as a hardware-centric data and instruction streaming problem.
Instead of treating the loop nest as a fixed computational construct, our
approach exposes its structure as a set of spatial and temporal mappings
governed by hardware parameters such as compute element distribution,
interconnect topology, and reconfigurability. This abstraction supports
lightweight, flexible deployment of convolution without reliance on heavyweight
transformations or reordering schemes. We demonstrate the application of our
approach on the MAVeC accelerator. We detail the implementation of convolution
operations in MAVeC and extend the framework to support full model execution on
VGG-16. Our profiling reveals high PE utilization (over 90%), significant fold
reuse, and scalable throughput up to 1.56 TFLOPs/sec and 12.7 KIPS for
end-to-end VGG-16 inference. These results validate the efficacy of our
approach in minimizing control overhead, improving data locality, and enabling
efficient large-scale convolution execution without reliance on conventional
transformation-based methods.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a framework that reinterprets 7D convolution loops for enhanced hardware-centric AI acceleration, achieving high performance without relying on traditional transformations.
AI.motivation: Convolution operations dominate AI workloads, often constituting 80-90% of the effort. Current approaches, like loop unrolling or GEMM-based transformations, add considerable overhead. A better methodology is required to optimize data movement and instruction control.
AI.method: The authors reconceptualize convolution loop nests as a hardware-centric data and instruction streaming problem. This is treated as a set of tunable spatial and temporal mappings based on hardware parameters like compute element distribution and interconnect topology. They implement this on the MAVeC accelerator and extend it to VGG-16 inference.
AI.result: PE utilization reached over 90%, with high fold reuse and scalable throughput of 1.56 TFLOPs/sec and 12.7 KIPS. The framework efficiently supports large convolution processes with minimal control and data overhead.
AI.conclusion: The proposed hardware-centric framework achieves efficient and flexible convolution processing on accelerators like MAVeC, avoiding reliance on traditional heavyweight transformations. This approach improves data locality and sustains high computational efficiency.

title: A Fast Parallel Median Filtering Algorithm Using Hierarchical Tiling
summary:
Median filtering is a non-linear smoothing technique widely used in digital
image processing to remove noise while retaining sharp edges. It is
particularly well suited to removing outliers (impulse noise) or granular
artifacts (speckle noise). However, the high computational cost of median
filtering can be prohibitive. Sorting-based algorithms excel with small kernels
but scale poorly with increasing kernel diameter, in contrast to constant-time
methods characterized by higher constant factors but better scalability, such
as histogram-based approaches or the 2D wavelet matrix.
  This paper introduces a novel algorithm, leveraging the separability of the
sorting problem through hierarchical tiling to minimize redundant computations.
We propose two variants: a data-oblivious selection network that can operate
entirely within registers, and a data-aware version utilizing random-access
memory. These achieve per-pixel complexities of $O(k \log(k))$ and $O(k)$,
respectively, for a $k \times k$ kernel - unprecedented for sorting-based
methods. Our CUDA implementation is up to 5 times faster than the current state
of the art on a modern GPU and is the fastest median filter in most cases for
8-, 16-, and 32-bit data types and kernels from $3 \times 3$ to $75 \times 75$.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a novel median filtering algorithm leveraging hierarchical tiling, achieving unprecedented efficiency with a CUDA implementation up to 5x faster than current methods on GPUs.
AI.motivation: The high computational cost of median filtering, especially with increasing kernel sizes, presents a challenge in digital image processing, necessitating a more efficient approach.
AI.method: Two algorithm variants are proposed: a data-oblivious selection network for on-register operations, and a data-aware method utilizing RAM. These yield per-pixel complexities of O(k log(k)) and O(k), respectively, leveraging hierarchical tiling to reduce redundant computations.
AI.result: The presented algorithms outperform existing state-of-the-art approaches, with the CUDA implementation demonstrating up to 5x speed improvements across various data types and kernel sizes.
AI.conclusion: The proposed algorithms significantly enhance the scalability and performance of median filtering, setting a new standard in computational efficiency for image processing tasks.

title: Directly Learning Stock Trading Strategies Through Profit Guided Loss Functions
comment:
17 pages, 4 figures, Submitted to Neural Information Processing
  Systems 2025
summary:
Stock trading has always been a challenging task due to the highly volatile
nature of the stock market. Making sound trading decisions to generate profit
is particularly difficult under such conditions. To address this, we propose
four novel loss functions to drive decision-making for a portfolio of stocks.
These functions account for the potential profits or losses based with respect
to buying or shorting respective stocks, enabling potentially any artificial
neural network to directly learn an effective trading strategy. Despite the
high volatility in stock market fluctuations over time, training time-series
models such as transformers on these loss functions resulted in trading
strategies that generated significant profits on a portfolio of 50 different
S&P 500 company stocks as compared to a benchmark reinforcment learning
techniques and a baseline buy and hold method. As an example, using 2021, 2022
and 2023 as three test periods, the Crossformer model adapted with our best
loss function was most consistent, resulting in returns of 51.42%, 51.04% and
48.62% respectively. In comparison, the best performing state-of-the-art
reinforcement learning methods, PPO and DDPG, only delivered maximum profits of
around 41%, 2.81% and 41.58% for the same periods. The code is available at
https://anonymous.4open.science/r/bandit-stock-trading-58C8/README.md.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes four novel loss functions for stock trading strategies, evaluated with time-series models like transformers, outperforming state-of-the-art reinforcement learning methods and a buy-and-hold baseline.
AI.motivation: The difficulty of making profitable stock trading decisions due to the volatile nature of the stock market.
AI.method: Developed four novel loss functions for stock trading and trained time-series models (e.g., transformers) to implicitly learn effective trading strategies based on these losses.
AI.result: The proposed losses integrated into models achieved notable returns (up to ~51% during 2021-2023), surpassing popular RL methods PPO and DDPG which achieved significantly lower profits for the same periods.
AI.conclusion: The proposed loss functions effectively guide models to develop robust trading strategies, demonstrating consistent and superior performance against benchmarks in highly volatile stock market scenarios.

title: Alignment and Safety in Large Language Models: Safety Mechanisms, Training Paradigms, and Emerging Challenges
summary:
Due to the remarkable capabilities and growing impact of large language
models (LLMs), they have been deeply integrated into many aspects of society.
Thus, ensuring their alignment with human values and intentions has emerged as
a critical challenge. This survey provides a comprehensive overview of
practical alignment techniques, training protocols, and empirical findings in
LLM alignment. We analyze the development of alignment methods across diverse
paradigms, characterizing the fundamental trade-offs between core alignment
objectives. Our analysis shows that while supervised fine-tuning enables basic
instruction-following, preference-based methods offer more flexibility for
aligning with nuanced human intent. We discuss state-of-the-art techniques,
including Direct Preference Optimization (DPO), Constitutional AI,
brain-inspired methods, and alignment uncertainty quantification (AUQ),
highlighting their approaches to balancing quality and efficiency. We review
existing evaluation frameworks and benchmarking datasets, emphasizing
limitations such as reward misspecification, distributional robustness, and
scalable oversight. We summarize strategies adopted by leading AI labs to
illustrate the current state of practice. We conclude by outlining open
problems in oversight, value pluralism, robustness, and continuous alignment.
This survey aims to inform both researchers and practitioners navigating the
evolving landscape of LLM alignment.

AI.tldr: The paper surveys techniques, protocols, and findings in aligning large language models (LLMs) with human values, detailing methods, trade-offs, and key challenges.
AI.motivation: The widespread use and societal integration of LLMs require ensuring their alignment with human values and intentions to mitigate potential risks.
AI.method: The authors analyze alignment paradigms, review state-of-the-art techniques like DPO and Constitutional AI, assess evaluation frameworks, and highlight AI lab strategies.
AI.result: The paper identifies core trade-offs in alignment objectives, discusses the strengths of various alignment methods, and reviews challenges in evaluation and oversight.
AI.conclusion: While progress has been made, significant open problems remain in oversight, robustness, value pluralism, and continuous alignment, necessitating further research for practical LLM alignment.

title: Predicting Brain Responses To Natural Movies With Multimodal LLMs
summary:
We present MedARC's team solution to the Algonauts 2025 challenge. Our
pipeline leveraged rich multimodal representations from various
state-of-the-art pretrained models across video (V-JEPA2), speech (Whisper),
text (Llama 3.2), vision-text (InternVL3), and vision-text-audio
(Qwen2.5-Omni). These features extracted from the models were linearly
projected to a latent space, temporally aligned to the fMRI time series, and
finally mapped to cortical parcels through a lightweight encoder comprising a
shared group head plus subject-specific residual heads. We trained hundreds of
model variants across hyperparameter settings, validated them on held-out
movies and assembled ensembles targeted to each parcel in each subject. Our
final submission achieved a mean Pearson's correlation of 0.2085 on the test
split of withheld out-of-distribution movies, placing our team in fourth place
for the competition. We further discuss a last-minute optimization that would
have raised us to second place. Our results highlight how combining features
from models trained in different modalities, using a simple architecture
consisting of shared-subject and single-subject components, and conducting
comprehensive model selection and ensembling improves generalization of
encoding models to novel movie stimuli. All code is available on GitHub.

AI.tldr: The paper details MedARC's multi-modal deep learning approach for the Algonauts 2025 challenge, achieving a 4th place ranking.
AI.motivation: To improve the generalization of encoding models for mapping cortical parcel activities from fMRI data by leveraging multimodal pretrained models.
AI.method: Used multimodal state-of-the-art pretrained models (e.g., V-JEPA2 for video, Whisper for speech) as feature extractors, followed by latent space projection, temporal alignment, and mapping to cortical parcels using an ensemble-based lightweight encoder framework.
AI.result: Achieved a mean Pearson correlation score of 0.2085 on withheld out-of-distribution movies, placing 4th in the competition.
AI.conclusion: Combining multimodal pretrained features with a simple architecture and comprehensive model selection significantly enhances the generalization of brain encoding models.

title: Defining ethically sourced code generation
summary:
Several code generation models have been proposed to help reduce time and
effort in solving software-related tasks. To ensure responsible AI, there are
growing interests over various ethical issues (e.g., unclear licensing,
privacy, fairness, and environment impact). These studies have the overarching
goal of ensuring ethically sourced generation, which has gained growing
attentions in speech synthesis and image generation. In this paper, we
introduce the novel notion of Ethically Sourced Code Generation (ES-CodeGen) to
refer to managing all processes involved in code generation model development
from data collection to post-deployment via ethical and sustainable practices.
To build a taxonomy of ES-CodeGen, we perform a two-phase literature review
where we read 803 papers across various domains and specific to AI-based code
generation. We identified 71 relevant papers with 10 initial dimensions of
ES-CodeGen. To refine our dimensions and gain insights on consequences of
ES-CodeGen, we surveyed 32 practitioners, which include six developers who
submitted GitHub issues to opt-out from the Stack dataset (these impacted users
have real-world experience of ethically sourcing issues in code generation
models). The results lead to 11 dimensions of ES-CodeGen with a new dimension
on code quality as practitioners have noted its importance. We also identified
consequences, artifacts, and stages relevant to ES-CodeGen. Our post-survey
reflection showed that most practitioners tend to ignore social-related
dimensions despite their importance. Most practitioners either agreed or
strongly agreed that our survey help improve their understanding of ES-CodeGen.
Our study calls for attentions of various ethical issues towards ES-CodeGen.

AI.tldr: This paper focuses on introducing and exploring Ethically Sourced Code Generation (ES-CodeGen) by reviewing literature and surveying practitioners to establish a taxonomy and dimensions associated with ethical practices in AI-based code generation.
AI.motivation: To address ethical concerns (like unclear licensing and privacy) in the development and deployment of code generation models.
AI.method: The authors performed a two-phase literature review (803 papers examined, 71 identified as relevant) and surveyed 32 practitioners to build and refine a taxonomy for ES-CodeGen.
AI.result: The research identified 11 dimensions of ES-CodeGen, with an added emphasis on code quality, based on practitioner feedback. They also outlined the consequences, artifacts, and stages relevant to ES-CodeGen.
AI.conclusion: The study emphasizes the importance of addressing overlooked social dimensions and ethical issues, and it demonstrates the potential of surveys to enhance practitioners' understanding of ES-CodeGen.

title: Predicting Parkinson's Disease Progression Using Statistical and Neural Mixed Effects Models: A Comparative Study on Longitudinal Biomarkers
summary:
Predicting Parkinson's Disease (PD) progression is crucial, and voice
biomarkers offer a non-invasive method for tracking symptom severity (UPDRS
scores) through telemonitoring. Analyzing this longitudinal data is challenging
due to within-subject correlations and complex, nonlinear patient-specific
progression patterns. This study benchmarks LMMs against two advanced hybrid
approaches: the Generalized Neural Network Mixed Model (GNMM) (Mandel 2021),
which embeds a neural network within a GLMM structure, and the Neural Mixed
Effects (NME) model (Wortwein 2023), allowing nonlinear subject-specific
parameters throughout the network. Using the Oxford Parkinson's telemonitoring
voice dataset, we evaluate these models' performance in predicting Total UPDRS
to offer practical guidance for PD research and clinical applications.

AI.tldr: The study compares various models to predict Parkinson's Disease (PD) progression using voice biomarkers.
AI.motivation: To utilize voice biomarkers for non-invasive tracking of Parkinson's Disease progression and UPDRS scores, addressing challenges like complex and nonlinear longitudinal data.
AI.method: The study benchmarks Linear Mixed Models (LMMs) against two advanced neural-hybrid approaches: GNMM and NME, utilizing the Oxford Parkinson's telemonitoring voice dataset for evaluation.
AI.result: The models' performance is analyzed by predicting Total UPDRS scores, providing insights into their practical use in PD research and clinical contexts.
AI.conclusion: Advanced hybrid neural-network-based models show promise in tracking PD progression, offering valuable tools for telemonitoring applications.

title: PhysVarMix: Physics-Informed Variational Mixture Model for Multi-Modal Trajectory Prediction
summary:
Accurate prediction of future agent trajectories is a critical challenge for
ensuring safe and efficient autonomous navigation, particularly in complex
urban environments characterized by multiple plausible future scenarios. In
this paper, we present a novel hybrid approach that integrates learning-based
with physics-based constraints to address the multi-modality inherent in
trajectory prediction. Our method employs a variational Bayesian mixture model
to effectively capture the diverse range of potential future behaviors, moving
beyond traditional unimodal assumptions. Unlike prior approaches that
predominantly treat trajectory prediction as a data-driven regression task, our
framework incorporates physical realism through sector-specific boundary
conditions and Model Predictive Control (MPC)-based smoothing. These
constraints ensure that predicted trajectories are not only data-consistent but
also physically plausible, adhering to kinematic and dynamic principles.
Furthermore, our method produces interpretable and diverse trajectory
predictions, enabling enhanced downstream decision-making and planning in
autonomous driving systems. We evaluate our approach on two benchmark datasets,
demonstrating superior performance compared to existing methods. Comprehensive
ablation studies validate the contributions of each component and highlight
their synergistic impact on prediction accuracy and reliability. By balancing
data-driven insights with physics-informed constraints, our approach offers a
robust and scalable solution for navigating the uncertainties of real-world
urban environments.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a novel hybrid method combining machine learning and physics-based constraints for predicting diverse and plausible autonomous vehicle trajectories in complex urban environments, achieving superior performance over existing methods.
AI.motivation: The study aims to tackle the challenge of accurate and safe prediction of future agent trajectories in urban environments, which are characterized by multiple possible scenarios, to enhance autonomous navigation.
AI.method: The approach integrates a variational Bayesian mixture model for capturing diverse behaviors with physics-based constraints using sector-specific boundary conditions and Model Predictive Control to ensure physically plausible trajectory predictions.
AI.result: The method outperformed existing models on two benchmark datasets. Ablation studies confirmed that each component contributed to better prediction accuracy and reliability.
AI.conclusion: By combining data-driven insights with physics-informed constraints, this hybrid framework provides an effective, scalable, and interpretable solution for autonomous trajectory prediction in real-world urban settings.

title: Efficient Attention Mechanisms for Large Language Models: A Survey
summary:
Transformer-based architectures have become the prevailing backbone of large
language models. However, the quadratic time and memory complexity of
self-attention remains a fundamental obstacle to efficient long-context
modeling. To address this limitation, recent research has introduced two
principal categories of efficient attention mechanisms. Linear attention
methods achieve linear complexity through kernel approximations, recurrent
formulations, or fastweight dynamics, thereby enabling scalable inference with
reduced computational overhead. Sparse attention techniques, in contrast, limit
attention computation to selected subsets of tokens based on fixed patterns,
block-wise routing, or clustering strategies, enhancing efficiency while
preserving contextual coverage. This survey provides a systematic and
comprehensive overview of these developments, integrating both algorithmic
innovations and hardware-level considerations. In addition, we analyze the
incorporation of efficient attention into largescale pre-trained language
models, including both architectures built entirely on efficient attention and
hybrid designs that combine local and global components. By aligning
theoretical foundations with practical deployment strategies, this work aims to
serve as a foundational reference for advancing the design of scalable and
efficient language models.

AI.tldr: The paper surveys efficient attention mechanisms for large language models to mitigate self-attention's high complexity, focusing on linear and sparse attention methods.
AI.motivation: To tackle the challenge of quadratic time and memory complexity in self-attention for long-context modeling in large language models.
AI.method: The study systematically categorizes and evaluates efficient attention approaches, integrates algorithmic advancements and hardware considerations, and examines their application in large-scale pre-trained language models.
AI.result: Efficient attention mechanisms, both linear and sparse, are highlighted as viable solutions for reducing computational overhead while maintaining contextual understanding.
AI.conclusion: This survey serves as a foundational reference to guide the design and deployment of scalable and efficient language models leveraging advancements in efficient attention methods.

title: BikeVAE-GNN: A Variational Autoencoder-Augmented Hybrid Graph Neural Network for Sparse Bicycle Volume Estimation
comment:
This paper has been accepted for publication in the Proceedings of
  the $28^{th}$ IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Transportation
  Systems (ITSC 2025). This is the author's version of the work
summary:
Accurate link-level bicycle volume estimation is essential for informed urban
and transport planning but it is challenged by extremely sparse count data in
urban bicycling networks worldwide. We propose BikeVAE-GNN, a novel dual-task
framework augmenting a Hybrid Graph Neural Network (GNN) with Variational
Autoencoder (VAE) to estimate Average Daily Bicycle (ADB) counts, addressing
sparse bicycle networks. The Hybrid-GNN combines Graph Convolutional Networks
(GCN), Graph Attention Networks (GAT), and GraphSAGE to effectively model
intricate spatial relationships in sparse networks while VAE generates
synthetic nodes and edges to enrich the graph structure and enhance the
estimation performance. BikeVAE-GNN simultaneously performs - regression for
bicycling volume estimation and classification for bicycling traffic level
categorization. We demonstrate the effectiveness of BikeVAE-GNN using
OpenStreetMap data and publicly available bicycle count data within the City of
Melbourne - where only 141 of 15,933 road segments have labeled counts
(resulting in 99% count data sparsity). Our experiments show that BikeVAE-GNN
outperforms machine learning and baseline GNN models, achieving a mean absolute
error (MAE) of 30.82 bicycles per day, accuracy of 99% and F1-score of 0.99.
Ablation studies further validate the effective role of Hybrid-GNN and VAE
components. Our research advances bicycling volume estimation in sparse
networks using novel and state-of-the-art approaches, providing insights for
sustainable bicycling infrastructures.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces BikeVAE-GNN, a dual-task framework combining Variational Autoencoder and Hybrid Graph Neural Network to estimate cycling volumes in sparse urban bicycling networks.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to solve the challenge of estimating cycling volumes in urban areas where bicycle count data is extremely sparse, which is crucial for sustainable urban and transport planning.
AI.method: BikeVAE-GNN utilizes a Hybrid Graph Neural Network incorporating GCN, GAT, and GraphSAGE to capture spatial relationships and a Variational Autoencoder to synthetically augment the graph with nodes and edges.
AI.result: The proposed model achieved a mean absolute error of 30.82 bicycles per day, with an accuracy of 99% and F1-score of 0.99, evaluated on highly sparse bicycling counts from Melbourne.
AI.conclusion: BikeVAE-GNN significantly enhances the ability to estimate and categorize bicycling traffic levels in sparse data environments, providing useful insights for the development of sustainable cycling infrastructure.

title: Object-centric Video Question Answering with Visual Grounding and Referring
summary:
Video Large Language Models (VideoLLMs) have recently demonstrated remarkable
progress in general video understanding. However, existing models primarily
focus on high-level comprehension and are limited to text-only responses,
restricting the flexibility for object-centric, multiround interactions. In
this paper, we make three contributions: (i) we address these limitations by
introducing a VideoLLM model, capable of performing both object referring for
input and grounding for output in video reasoning tasks, i.e., allowing users
to interact with videos using both textual and visual prompts; (ii) we propose
STOM (Spatial-Temporal Overlay Module), a novel approach that propagates
arbitrary visual prompts input at any single timestamp to the remaining frames
within a video; (iii) we present VideoInfer, a manually curated object-centric
video instruction dataset featuring questionanswering pairs that require
reasoning. We conduct comprehensive experiments on VideoInfer and other
existing benchmarks across video question answering and referring object
segmentation. The results on 12 benchmarks of 6 tasks show that our proposed
model consistently outperforms baselines in both video question answering and
segmentation, underscoring its robustness in multimodal, object-centric video
and image understanding. Project page:
https://qirui-chen.github.io/RGA3-release/.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a VideoLLM model capable of both textual and visual prompt-based video interaction, leveraging a proposed STOM module and a curated dataset, achieving state-of-the-art results in video understanding tasks.
AI.motivation: Existing VideoLLMs primarily focus on high-level comprehension and lack flexibility in object-centric multiround interactions using both textual and visual prompts.
AI.method: The proposed method includes development of the VideoLLM model with object referring and grounding capabilities, introduction of the STOM module for propagating visual prompts, and creation of the VideoInfer dataset for object-centric video reasoning.
AI.result: Extensive experiments across 12 benchmarks demonstrate the proposed model's superiority in video question answering and segmentation tasks.
AI.conclusion: The model extends the flexibility and robustness of VideoLLMs, showcasing advancements in multimodal, object-centric video understanding.

title: Smaller, Faster, Cheaper: Architectural Designs for Efficient Machine Learning
summary:
Major advancements in the capabilities of computer vision models have been
primarily fueled by rapid expansion of datasets, model parameters, and
computational budgets, leading to ever-increasing demands on computational
infrastructure. However, as these models are deployed in increasingly diverse
and resource-constrained environments, there is a pressing need for
architectures that can deliver high performance while requiring fewer
computational resources.
  This dissertation focuses on architectural principles through which models
can achieve increased performance while reducing their computational demands.
We discuss strides towards this goal through three directions. First, we focus
on data ingress and egress, investigating how information may be passed into
